title: Client Report - Project 1
text:
paste your elevator pitch here A SHORT (4-5 SENTENCES) PARAGRAPH THAT DESCRIBES KEY INSIGHTS TAKEN FROM METRICS IN THE PROJECT RESULTS THINK TOP OR MOST IMPORTANT RESULTS.


Read and format project data
# Include and execute your code here
df = pd.read_csv("https://github.com/byuidatascience/data4names/raw/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv")


Highlight the Questions and Tasks

title: Client Report - Project 1
text:
paste your elevator pitch here A SHORT (4-5 SENTENCES) PARAGRAPH THAT DESCRIBES KEY INSIGHTS TAKEN FROM METRICS IN THE PROJECT RESULTS THINK TOP OR MOST IMPORTANT RESULTS.


Read and format project data
# Include and execute your code here
df = pd.read_csv("https://github.com/byuidatascience/data4names/raw/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv")


Highlight the Questions and Tasks

title: Client Report - Project 1
text:
QUESTION 1
How does your name at your birth year compare to its use historically?
Kevin is a name that in US started to be used around 1940. In 20 years the name utilization increased 2100% reaching his peak in 1963. After this date the name is tending to be less used 


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
x =df.loc[(df["name"]=="Kevin")]
# xa =df.loc[df["name"]=="Oliver"]
# print(xa)
chart2 = px.line(x, 
x="year", y="Total",
title = "The use of the name Kevin in the last 100 years").update_layout(title_x=0.45).add_vline(x=1963, line_width=2, line_dash="dash", annotation_text="Peak", line_color="red")

chart2.show()

# counts = df['name'].value_counts()
# qwe = xa["UT"].sum()
# print(qwe)
#print(counts["Oliver"])


                                                


include figures in chunks and discuss your findings in the figure.


table example
# Include and execute your code here
# means = df.sort_values("name", ascending=False).


# display(mydat)

title: Client Report - Project 1
text:
QUESTION|TASK 2
If you talked to someone named Brittany on the phone, what is your guess of his or her age? What ages would you not guess?
If I would guess a age, I would say 34 years old or around it, because it is the peak of the numbers of names. I would not say any age less than 23 years old or more than 41 years old. In this range we will have 90% less than people around 34 years old.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
x =df.loc[(df["name"]=="Brittany")]
chart1 = px.line(x, 
x="year", y="Total",
title = "The use of the name Brittany in the last 100 years").update_layout(title_x=0.45).add_vline(x=1990, line_width=2, line_dash="dash", annotation_text="Peak", line_color="red")


chart1.show()


                                                


include figures in chunks and discuss your findings in the figure.

title: Client Report - Project 1
text:
QUESTION|TASK 3
Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul are all Christian names. From 1920 - 2000, compare the name usage of each of the four names. What trends do you notice?
They had a great surge on 1915 followed by a slight decrease in the utilization in the year 1928 until 1936, when they started to appear in a huge amount again, in the year 1954 it started to diminush and this trend is followed until the last data we had which is from 2014. During all period, a total of 4826973 people received one of these names.


Show the code
x =df.query("name == ['Mary','Martha','Peter','Paul']")
z =x['Total'].sum()
chart1 = px.line(x, 
x="year", y="Total",
title = "Utilization of the names Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul over 100 years", color='name').update_layout(title_x=0.45).add_vline(x=1950, line_width=2, line_dash="dash", annotation_text="Peak", line_color="red")

chart1.show()

title: Client Report - Project 1
text:
QUESTION|TASK 4
Think of a unique name from a famous movie. Plot the usage of that name and see how changes line up with the movie release. Does it look like the movie had an effect on usage?
It doesn’t like to have a strict relationship between the event of the raising in the name usage and the release of the movie, the name started to raise even before the movie, and the name usage had a similar pattern before. 


Show the code
a =df.query("name == 'Rocky'")

chart3 = px.line(a, 
x="year", y="Total",
title = "Rocky name usage over 100 years", color='name').update_layout(title_x=0.45).add_vline(x=1976, line_width=2, line_dash="dash", annotation_text="Release", line_color="red")

chart3.show()
